115211.content:
The purple drake grabbed the rabbits limp hand and gave it a gentle shake. “My name is Tyler.” He introduced himself. “But to be honest, I have no idea what happened. I was just walking past your house and it sort of… exploded. I pulled you out of the rubble just now.” Tyler explained, before adding “You didn’t have a pulse or anything.” He knew it was an unnecessary and immodest addition, but he couldn’t help himself.

The rabbit didn’t seem to respond as he expected though. His brow simply furrowed in confusion as he tried to take that in. “The house exploded?” he asked uncomprehendingly. Tyler nodded and gestured to the pile of rubble that was barely visible in the streetlight through the dispersing dust. Tyler was suddenly aware of the figures standing visible in the distance around them.

Well, Tyler guessed that you would expect some onlookers to come out if they heard a house explode. “Hey, can someone call an ambulance for this guy?” He called out to the onlookers in general.

“No!” the rabbit said suddenly sitting up, grabbing Tyler’s knee. “No, don’t do that. I can’t afford to go to hospital. I’ll be fine, don’t call anyone” he pleaded.

Tyler was seriously taken aback. “But… it’s your health man, You weren’t breathing or anything, and you’re bleeding a bit, and your lungs would be caked in dust, there’s be little bits of plaster and glass and god knows what else in your lungs…” tyler trailed off. That last bit probably applied to him too, he thought dimly.

“No, I’ll be fine, please tell them to stop.” The rabbit pleaded. Tyler sighed, and instructed the crowd not to bother.
“It’s too late, we called a long time ago… the police will be here too I imagine.” A woman called from the haze. Tyler couldn’t tell if she meant to shout that threateningly.

The rabbit looked panicked. Tyler couldn’t help but laugh. “Come on man, this isn’t the worst thing to happen to you today. Come on…” He sat up prone on his knees, offering a hand to the white Rabbit. “Lets get out of this damned dust, there’s plenty of clean air down the road.”

The rabbit groggily got to his feet and lent heavily on the purple Drake as they made their way past the strewn debris that littered the street. The rabbit was truly short, his head only reaching Tyler’s shoulder. “So man, I still don’t know your name.” Tyler prompted as they made their way towards two of the onlookers. They were a middle aged avian couple of some kind.

“Rob.” The rabbit coughed. “My name is Rob, sorry I’ve forgotten yours.” The rabbit apologised, before sheepishly muttering “sorry, I’m bad with names.”

“Tyler.” The purple drake repeated. “And don’t worry about it, I’m sure that you’ve got a lot to take in, and my name wouldn’t rank very highly.”

The female bird asked if they wanted water or a blanket. Rob nodded and she disappeared inside. Tyler realised that he was actually very thirsty. And hungry. And tired. And Dirty.

They had another moment trade dialogue with each other. Rob was 19, and just got in from overseas a few days ago to start at college. He was still catching up on the time zone and was sleeping when his house exploded. His face lit up when Tyler mentioned that he was attending the same campus. That ignited another round of discussion until they were interrupted by the approaching sirens.

It felt like a very small, very serious circus quickly set itself up around the street in the moments that followed. Representatives from the Police, ambulance, fire brigade, council, news casts, and onlookers from neighbouring suburbs swarmed the street, and the processions from that evening quickly degenerated into a sensory blur.

Police Interviewed Tyler, at times very aggressively. He was walking home from his shop. Yes, he had ID and could verify his shop and house address. No, he didn’t see what started the explosion. No, he didn’t have a clear view of it. He found Rob under debris when he pulled him out. No, he didn’t see anything suspicious in the debris. No, neither he nor Rob had any opportunity to tamper with anything after the explosion. Because Rob was unconscious and not breathing.

Tyler felt a bit cheated. He thought he was a hero, but the way the police were grilling every aspect of his story made him shake in intimidation. Then the ambulance treated him. There was nothing wrong with him, but they hooked him up to some sort of breathing machine for a time anyway. The street was flashing red and blue from the fire engines that blocked the narrow suburban street as firemen illuminated the lot with floodlights as they carefully searched the debris.

At some point there was a camera in his face. He recoiled but the camera just got closer. Someone was asking him a question. He didn’t hear it. His eyes darted between the lens and the light that blinded him.. “um…’ he began as his mind tried to ground himself. “There was some sort of an explosion, and the house exploded” he offered dumbly.

“What do you say about reports of a missile launch? Was this a terrorist attack?” a reporter desperately demanded from the darkness. “…what?” Tyler asked dumbfounded. “Several eyewitnesses claim a missile struck the house, can you confirm this?” The reporter asked so quickly he could hardly parse the words, let alone sentence. Tyler stood a moment with his mouth open . “uh… no, there was… I just saw an explosion.”

Then the police stepped in between them and it was over. He was ushered behind a van. Someone offered him a hot chocolate. Where was Rob? He hadn’t seen the rabbit since the first flashing light arrived.

The night seemed to last forever, but eventually the crowd finally started to thin. By midnight there was only a single fire truck and a handful of patrol cars. A handful of figures still searched through the rubble or idle doing who knows what, but for the most part the circus had left.

Finally Rob appeared, being guided out of a neighbouring house by two rather tall German Shepards. They walked him over to a rather fat looking beaver that was leaning on his patrol car. “Ok, so he’s been briefed.” The beaver was informed by one of the dogs accompanying Rob.

“So you understand that you’ll be reporting in regularly? And the consequences of failing to comply?” the fat beacer asked the rabbit sternly.

Rob could only manage a weak nod. He looked exhausted – both physically and psychologically. He pointedly avoided eye contact.

“Do you have anywhere else to stay at in the mean time?” The beaver asked rather formally. Rob shook his head.
“Well, we can take you to a hotel if you have the funds to pay it.”

Rob’s eyes darted to where his house used to be. “No, sir. I think it’s all gone now with everything else.”
“You don’t have any bank accounts you can draw money from?

Rob shook his head again. “Not in this country sir, not yet.” Not once did he look at any of them.

“Well what the fuck do we do with him now then?” The beaver demanded impatiently to the two shepherds.

One of them half shrugged. “Well, we can move some people around and clear out one of the lockups for him if he’s happy to spend the night at the station…” he suggested.

“No!” Tyler interjected. All three of them turned to the purple drake simultaneously, but the angle of light obscured their expressions. “He can stay at my place.”

There was a brief pause. “You’re statements say you don’t know each other…” one of the dogs began. “For safety reasons of both parties, we would only recommend his stays with close friends or family…”

“Hey rabbit, is that alright with you? “ The beaver interrupted impatiently. “Are you happy to stay with the dragon over there?”

Rob looked nervously up at Tyler.
115211.title: “What happened? Who are you?”

choices: Tyler realises there is something odd about himself when he wakes up.
Tyler realises there is something odd about Rob when he wakes up.
1152111.content:
“Then that’s good enough for me.” The beaver huffed as he turned back to his patrol car. “Come on Mic, it’s time to go home. Its late enough as it is.” One of the dogs walked around and got in the passenger side door. The car rolling before the door closed, not a single hesitation as it turned and sped away from the scene.

The remaining German Shepard walked Rob over to Tyler. “I assume you guys must be pretty shaken up right now, it’s been a big night hasn’t it? Did you want me to give you a lift?” He was addressing Tyler, Rob was only implied.
Tyler’s eyes flicked between Rob and the cop. “I suppose… that would be awesome, if you wouldn’t mind actually… I live just down…”

“I know where you live.” the dog interrupted, but not aggressively. “Come on, it’s getting late.

No one said a single word on the drive the drive back to Tyler’s house. They had nothing to say to each other. Rob had been interviewed for hours, Tyler already had everything worthwhile on record, and the dog already knew more than he would ever need to about both of them.

It was the most awkward five minutes of his life, the silence only punctuated by the dog telling them to take care as they exited the vehicle.

David was playing some shooter on the Xbox as they walked inside. The yahoo frat boy style arcade shooter was the only computer game he would touch, but he would play it often enough in his downtime to make up for his narrow pallet.
David called out to them as he watched them enter the house. “Oh fuck Tyler, if you had have called me to let me know you were bringing a party home, I could have prepared something…”

“Shut up David, it’s been a long night.” Then a thought occurred. “Have you seen anything on the TV?” he asked innocently.

“Nup, haven’t been watching it. Why?”

“Never mind, Just curious” Tyler trailed off.

“No, but seriously Tyler.” David pushed. “Who is that guy?” he asked, flicking his head at the rabbit.

“This is Rob. He’ll be staying with us here in the study tonight. Oh, and Rob, this is my brother David. I probably should have told you about him.” Tyler apologised, but between spotting his unconscious foot and walking into the house, he couldn’t think of where he could have squeezed it in.

“Aren’t you two hipsters getting a little old for the slumber parties?” he asked with a raised eyebrow.

“I said shut up David, don’t be rude to guests, not tonight.”

“Tomorrow morning then.” David agreed, turning his attention back to the xbox. “But tell your friend that I can smell him from here, and that he should have a shower before he comes around next time. But don’t be rude about it or anything.”

“Ignore him, he’s not actually this hostile, he’s just showing off.” Tyler assured the rabbit loudly enough for his brother to hear. Without dividing his attention from his game, David grinned. “Sounds like a challenge.”

Tyler led Rob upstairs. “You must have been in that house for hours man… with the cops, I mean. What took you so long to talk about?”

“Well…” The rabbit began hesitantly. “When I told them I was a foreign student, that I wasn’t a citizen, they seemed to just assume I was a terrorist.” He began calmly, though he was clearly suppressing how upset he was. “And then they demanded to see my passport, but that’s obviously buried in the rubble or spread out over the street, like everything else I own… owned now I guess. I thought that would be obvious, but it wasn’t obvious, they demanded my passport over and over again… they said they would arrest me and not let me go, that I …” his voice was growing more hysterical as he spoke, until he finally ended up choking on his own words.

“It’s ok man…” Tyler said, patting him awkwardly on the back. How should one console a virtual stranger? “We’re here now; they’ve let you go… It’s all working out.” Should he be saying that? It sounded kind of patronising.

Rob nodded, taking a few moments to compose himself before rubbing his dusty eyes with his dusty forearm. “Yeah… sorry” he said apologetically. “I have to report in to them every day, and seek immediate consular assistance. Hopefully they find my passport in the rubble or something. They said they would let me know if they found anything. I don’t even have any proper clothes, or my wallet. I only had one unpacked suitcase and that’s all gone now.”

He suddenly pulled himself from his thoughts and laughed. “So yeah, thanks for letting me come over and everything, it’s very kind and greatly appreciated.”

Tyler had to consciously help his smile form. AND I saved your life, he thought almost angrily. I pulled you from the house and made your heart beat. Why is this not a thing? “Don’t worry about it. David’s an ass, but he’s right. We both need a shower. And you’re going to need something else to change into.”

Tyler went looking in his room for some clothes he could lend Rob. He smiled wryly to himself as he searched his wardrobe. Everything was going to be too big, which was a rather unique conundrum for him. “I hate to say it man, but I think the only things I have that will fit you will be some of my old teenage stuff.”

“That’s fine Tyler…” Rob assured him. “Anything is better than showing up tomorrow in this.”

Tyler cursed under his breath. I’ve got some bad news for you…” he said as he pulled out a box of old clothes. “I was a bit of a nerd in high school… actually, I didn’t need to qualify that. But still, my dress sense was slightly louder about it. You’re welcome to everything in this box, but I’d better apologise in advance for your eventual selection.”

Tyler showed Rob to the empty study, and organised a mattress and blankets while the rabbit showered. And then Ron went to bed.

Tyler was still far too worked up to call it a night just then. He went back downstairs after his shower. David had returned, leaving him free with the TV. He turned straight to the news, and perhaps unsurprisingly, they were talking about the exploding house thing.

He recognised the shots of the rubble as the presenters talked over the images, and some of the local ‘onlookers’ which they interviewed.

But he gasped when he saw some of the viewer footage. There were at least three shaky phone recordings of a projectile flying through the sky. It kind of looked like a rocket. But it looked like it was travelling far too fast, and breaking up as it moved along. Was the house struck by a meteor?

None of the videos showed the impact of course, the streak was just filemd flying over suburbia, not landing in it. But there were so many angles, showing recognisable chunks of the city, with the same dark, ominous clouds in the evening sky as there were this morning. He was convinced they were genuine. So the explosion was caused by a projectile.

And then he was on TV. He didn’t recognise himself straight away. The camera was shaking, the light was hard against his purple scales… but it was him. There were a number of voices , but a sole female rose above the crowd. “What did you see sir?” it demanded. Tyler stood frozen dumbly for a few seconds before… grunting? That was a grunt. A confused grunt.

Tyler buried his head in his hands as his face flushed red in embarrassment. Oh God, he couldn’t watch this. “There was some sort of an explosion, and the house exploded”, he heard his own voice coming from the television. Well… that was a quote for the ages, he thought to himself. Mercifully, the footage then cut to some more dark footage of the rubble and the news cast moved on. But Tyler remained head in hand, completely mortified. No, this wasn’t a moment he’d be sharing with his grandkids about.

“Well, it’s got to be asked now…” one of the news reporters began as they cut back into their studio. There were four of them, sitting on a panel. “An undocumented foreign student moves into suburbia, and two days later his house blows up. So we really have to be asking ourselves what we are opening our doors up to when we allow, when we share our city these kinds of people.”

“What?!” Tyler demanded his TV with exasperation. The newscaster continued “I mean, sure, we have to wait until all the facts are out, we can’t be getting ahead of ourselves here. But does anyone honestly believe something like this would have happened if a local student lived there? Has an event like this ever been recorded for local students?” He paused to allow the rest of the panel to either shrug or shake their heads. “No? This is how they can come into here…you know, fairly easily. Student visas are a real weakness for us. We need to be looking more critically at this area, or else the events of tonight will probably become increasingly common.”

Tyler turned the TV off. He hated politics at the best of times, but that was fucking ridiculous. They had no idea what they were talking about, but they were being paid to talk about it until the early morning hours, so they had to say something. His own little first-hand experience with news.

He let the frustration of the world’s troubles flow off him as he settled into bed. He reflected on the surprising twist in his day. He still felt hard done by, if this were a movie he’s have his picture in the paper holding a medal for his bravery and heroism. Perhaps it’s just a sign of the times. Or perhaps it was always just a fanciful portrayal of reality from TV and movies. Whatever the reason, eventually drifted off into sleep.

It wasn’t until Morning when things started to get weird.

11521112.content:
“I see you’ve one for the yellow Pokémon shirt, very nice.” Tyler half teased as Rob walked into the kitchen for breakfast the next morning. The rabbit gave a half embarrassed smile in response. “Yeah, well I thought it had a kind of retro look about it going on… so I figured why not?"

The shirt was slightly too small for Rob, but it wasn’t too bad a fit. The rabbit didn’t have much definition to show off, but he didn’t have an ounce of fat on him so his tight shirt didn’t look too out of place. Well, apart from the subject matter.

His shorts were a different story, however. The rabbit’s thighs… actually, his whole feet come to think about it, were actually quite thick and powerful proportionately. The short’s legs were stretched thin, their ends riding up a bit higher than they were designed, making them look even smaller on him.

“Shit man, we’ve got to get you some better clothes. Do you know Hardson’s Street?” the purple drake asked. The rabbit shook his head. “I don’t know any street names here yet sorry, but I imagine I can either ask around or Google it. Why?”
It’s the main road that leads north of campus, past the science faculty Building. There’s a charity shop up about fifteen minutes up there that should sell some clothes fairly cheaply. Here…’ Tyler said as he fished a 20 out of his wallet. “This should get you a small stack of stuff which you won’t mind getting caught dead in.”

Rob didn’t take the money. “No, I can’t take that, I’ve already taken too much.” Tyler rolled his eyes. “Please don’t make a game of this man, I imagine you’re gonna need some of it to eat lunch or something as well, right?” The rabbit didn’t respond. “So trust me dude, you need this more than me.” Tyler practically threw the money at him. “coffee?”

“If you’re making one” the rabbit replied nervously. “um…” he began as Tyler poured a cup. “Is David around?”

Tyler laughed. “If I don’t seem him, I don’t care. He usually starts exercising pretty early in the morning. Why? He hasn’t scared you has he? That’s what he wants to do, don’t give into him. Remember, he might live here, but this is my house.” He handed the coffee to Rob. “You know how to make toast?” he asked with a smile on his face, nodding to the table top. “Help yourself.”

“Thanks…” Rob murmured.

“So do you have to see the consular today?” Tyler intended to ask casually, but he realised it was probably a very heady question once he asked it. The rabbit nodded.

“I’ll try and make an appointment after class. I think, Well, I get the impression I should be going there first thing this morning, but I figure, what’s the point of being in the country if I don’t go to class anyway?”

Tyler nodded in approval. “Yeah, that’s a good attitude man. Look, to be honest the first week is always fairly useless. They just go over the course guide and give you a rough outline of dates and shit. It’s completely pointless, but some of those Professors can be… quite precious. It’s just good politics to show up on the first week. That’s something I’ve been trying to tell David for years, but he’s got his own view of the world I guess.”

The drake handed Rob a coffee. He held it carefully and sipped it, a confused look appearing on his face. He then took a mouthful.

“Is there something wrong?” Tyler asked.

“Oh, no… well, not really. Is… cold coffee a cultural thing, or is it meant to be hot?”

Tyler eyed the steam that rose from the cup in confusion, unable to bridge the logical disconnect. “Sorry, are you saying your coffee isn’t hot enough?” Was Rob a smartass?Is that what was happening here?

The rabbit looked around nervously. “no, it’s fine, it’s just… I wasn’t expecting it is all. It’s just, back home, we serve our coffee hot. I’ll get used to this. It’s very nice.”

“Are you trolling bro?” Tyler asked confused, a playful smile appearing on his face.

“No… I’m, I’m not trolling. Forget I mentioned anything.”

Tyler wanted to unravel this before he let it go. “Well, how hot do you want coffee? water only boils so hot…”

“Well, it’s not boiled. It’s room temperature.” The rabbit looked as confused as Tyler did.

“…. No, its very hot. I can see that it’s very hot.” Tyler said slowly and sceptically, still not entirely convinced that the rabbit was being genuine.

Until he dumped his finger into it and kept it there. “No, It’s only Luke warm, see?

Tyler’s eyes widened in shock as he reflexively slapped at the rabbit’s hand. “Fuck, don’t do that you idiot!” he shouted.

“Why?” The rabbit asked defensively confused at the drake’s response. He complied with the dragon’s request nonetheless.

“Because You’ll burn your finger!”.

“so it IS hot?” Rob asked flustered.

“its scolding! Look at the steam!”

“are you sure?”

“I’m positive!” Tyler practically shouted. “Can you seriously not feel the heat there at all?!”

“well…” the rabbit said hesitantly, looking incredibly self-aware and nervous as he held the hot cup in his hand. “its hard to say, but no? I mean, it feels as hot as the table… and that’s not hot…”

‘Dude, that’s fucked up!” Tyler cried out. “Are you feeling alright man?” he held out a hand to gesture that he wanted to feel the rabbit’s forehead. He completed the action when the rabbit didn’t resist.

“holy FUCK!” Tyler gasped. “Man, you’re temperature is cold!” he said stunned, ripping his hand form the rabbit’s head. He quickly felt up the rabbits arm. “Rob, this is serious, you feel like you’re dead. You aren’t even room temperature, I can feel my fingers going cold when I touch you.” He looked at the rabbit with mortified amazement. “You’ve got to go to the hospital right now!”

Rob probed his own body with his fingers. “I don’t feel cold…” he said to himself sceptically.

“Do you feel ANY temperature, hot or cold?” Tyler asked. Rob considered a moment. “I don’t know, it’s hard to tell.”
Tyler opened the freezer and collected a handful of ice cubes. “Well?” he demanded as he presented them to the rabbit.

Rob picked one out and clasped it between his hands for a moment, before concluding “No, this doesn’t feel cold.”

Tyler threw the rest of the ice he was holding into the sink. “Look at my fingers man!” The ice had left visible red marks in Tyler’s purple shaking fingers. “Do you see that ice burn? And you’re telling me you can’t feel anything?”

“No man, I promise I’m not lying!” the rabbit said defensively.

“I believe you!” Tyler pressed. “Which is why you have to go to hospital right now!”

“NO!” Rob said instinctively. “No, I mean” he said apologetically. “I mean, I feel fine. Great even , I don’t feel like…”

“You feel like a fucking corpse dude!” Tyler interjected. “One that has been sitting in a fridge for a few hours at that. I’m beginning to think I’ve revived a fucking zombie!”

“I’m not a zombie!” Rob protested. “I can feel my heart beating quite fast right now actually. Please calm down, I feel fine. Honestly, I feel better than fine. I slept well, and I even feel energetic for this time of the morning.”

Tyler eyed him sceptically. “The ice isn’t melting in your hand at all is it?” he asked flatly.

Rob stole a surprised glance at the ice cube in his hand. He forgot he was holding that. “No…” he said. “But I don’t have any freezer burn either, do I?”

“Because you’re too fucking cold for the ice to burn you!” Tyler explained slowly but forcefully.

Rob placed the ice on the table. “Do I look frozen solid to you?” He asked Tyler. “Or cold or otherwise lethargic? Trust me, I’m Fine Tyler. Don’t worry about me. I feel fine. Please calm down.”

115211121.content:
The purple drake shook his head. “I can’t believe this. Fine. It’s your life. But I’ve got my eye on you.”

“And I’m grateful for that…” the rabbit smiled in appreciation. “Did you want any toast?” He offered Tyler.

“Nah thanks, I had some earlier.” Tyler said as he sat back down. “So what time did your classes start?” he asked the rabbit as he went about making his breakfast.

“Nine thirty.” He replied.

“Well I start at ten, so I can walk you there and show you around some if you want.”

The rabbit smiled as he dropped the bread into the toaster. “Oh, yeah actually that’d be grea…”

Rob was cut off as the toaster violently shorted out . The loud “bang” was accompanied by a brilliant yellow flash of fire and a bolt of pure white electricity that shot straight up the rabbits hand.

“Hoar!” the rabbit cried out in surprise as the toaster started smoking. He had flinched, but it seemed more from surprise than an electric shock.

“holy FUCK man!” Tyler cried out startled, jumping to his feet again. “Are you alight?!”

The rabbit rubbed his hand distantly. “Yeah… yeah, totally fine. It shocked me, but it didn’t feel anything like I thought it would…”

“You’d have to be the most unluckiest rabbit alive” Tyler muttered, shaking his head in disbelief.

The rabbit visibly contemplated this, before smiling. “Or the luckiest!” he said cheerfully, before his expression dropped again. “But seriously, I’m sorry I just broke your toaster.”

“You didn’t do anything man, it’s just an old piece of shit by the looks of it. Hell, you could probably sue us over that.” Mmm, Tyler chastised himself. Probably didn’t need to point that out, just in case.

“Ha, well I could use the money.” The rabbit joked, cheering up again. “And when you think about it, bread and jelly is just as nutritious a breakfast anyway. And a lot fresher.”

The rest of breakfast past without incident. Tyler managed to keep the conversation going, and while it never really picked up, there wasn’t any awkward silences either.

Tyler lead them through he lounge as they left for school. “Fucking David.” He scowled as he saw that David had left the TV on since earlier in the morning. “How long do you think that’s been on for? He doesn’t care; he doesn’t ever worry too much about paying for the bills.”

“It’s ok, I’ll turn it off…” Rob said as he walked over to the screen. “No dude, its OK. There’s a remote…”
The rabbit shorted out the TV. It exploded with a loud bang, the burst of energy seeming to find its way through the surround sound system, leading to an incredibly loud combined explosion sound. The screen flashed white then died as another, more savage bolt of electricity shot up the rabbit’s hand.

They both stood still in wide eyed silence as the smell of burning electricity permeated through the room.

“Are you…” Tyler began.

“I’m fine.” Rob finished. “That didn’t hurt at all, or anything.” He lowered his gaze. “I fucking broke your TV.” He said angrily to himself.

“Don’t… don’t worry about that man, we’ll just have to be careful with you next time. Maybe you have some static charge built up or some shit that is giving you shocks and screwing with your temperature.” Tyler offered.

“Maybe…” Rob politely accepted.

Neither of them believed it.

“Come one then, I suppose…” Tyler said to get things rolling again.

He smiled as they filed out of the room. “You know you’re welcome to come back here again tonight if things don’t sort themselves out man.” Tyler reassured the rabbit. “Don’t hesitate. Though I might have to keep you away from the electrical equipment. “

“thanks…” the rabbit murmured sheepishly again. He was probably getting tired of saying that.

He looked over the rabbit as he led him out the door. Rob was a very small individual, there was no denying that. But he didn’t seem quite as small as he had when Tyler first lead him out of the dust last night. And while he didn’t have anything on his bones coming close to what you would consider to be definition, he wasn’t exactly as thin as a rake either.

“I’ve got the feeling you’re gonna have a good day man.” Tyler said, patting the rabbit on the back before abruptly recoiling. Damn, he shivered. The rabbit was so cold to touch. Don’t do that again.

1152111211.content:
That evening, Tyler was chilling out on the couch with his brother, collectively watching nothing on TV after a long day. They were interrupted by a knock on the door. Tyler had zoned out by this stage, the thought that the rabbit could be returning was simply not on his mind as he let his brother answer the door.

“Tyler, what the fuck is this?” David asked bluntly.

“What?” Tyler asked confused, suddenly realising that the person David was contemptuously eyeing through the doorway was probably Rob.

“Oh fucking hell David!” Tyler exclaimed as he jumped to his feet and quickly made his way to the door. “That’s fucking sick the way you treat… some…” Tyler trailed off as he saw the rabbit, gaping as the scene registered.

It was Rob, the short familiar white rabbit, and he was still wearing the small yellow Pokémon shirt and tight shorts that he had left the house in this morning. But these similarities aside, there was still a gaping disconnect between the rabbit who left the house to the rabbit who stood before him then.

He was bigger. Significantly so. He was almost eye level to Tyler now… six inches taller? He’s have to be at least that, the purple drake thought to himself amazed. At Rob’s height, six inches was a hell of a lot. He looked… almost like a completely different rabbit now.

The Pokémon shirt clung tightly to his torso, the faded yellow fabric being stretched so far that the fur on the rabbit’s chest was somewhat visible through it. His left sleeve had ripped several inches up the fabric, apparently unable to contain the bunny’s somewhat thicker arm. The other sleeve was in one piece, but was drawn so taught that it forced the rabbit’s arm onto a slightly unnatural angle.

The rabbit’s chest seemed to bow the front of the shit upwards, exposing several solid inches of white fur between the shirt and the pants, the bunny’s navel featuring in the centre of the hard, slat exposed stomach.

But it was the pants that were really straining. They were tight before, but now they were on a different level altogether. The fabric in the legs was completely at their limit, and while they were both still barely in one piece, it was only through some severe contortion of the rabbit’s powerful thighs. The shorts had ridden almost all the way up his legs, exposing far more fur than modesty would usually aim for.

And as the bottom of the pants pulled up, the elastic was being pulled down, barely hugging the rabbit’s hips. The elastic bowed further forward as it wrapped around the rabbit’s front, his groin pulling the fabric so tight that there was absolutely nothing left to the imagination. Tyler could even make out each individual testicle through the fabric.

It was not necessarily because the rabbit’s crotch was huge – it wasn’t. It wasn’t small either, mind. But the fabric stretching was caused mainly by the fabric being stretched out to accommodate the rabbit’s thighs, rather than his crotch filling it to the brim.

And overall, while the rabbit had earlier today looked rather thin and lanky, right now he looked… almost fit.
“uh… hi.” The rabbit said awkwardly, breaking the silence that had stretched on perhaps a little too long. He gave a feeble wave with his hand as if to make light of the situation, but the movement just tore the fabric on the other sleeve. David stared at the shirt wide eyed as he watched the fabric violently ricochet up the rabbits arm, before slowly

continuing to rip another inch or two before it settled.

“Um…” Tyler said hesitantly. “Hey, Rob... Please come in…”

11521112111.content:
“Ah, Tyler?!” David demanded, suddenly slamming a heavy hand on his shoulder. “A little word with you in the kitchen if you wouldn’t mind.” He used his grip to forcibly turn the purple drake and practically carry him into the kitchen.

Tyler was struggling by the end of it. “For fucks sake David, let go of me, Don’t fucking push me!” He protested angrily, squirming from his brother’s grip.

“Ok dude.” David said once they reached the kitchen, his tone low and severe, warning his brother that it was time to be absolutely serious. “Tell me what the fuck is going on with you and this rabbit?”

“What?!” Tyler demanded. “You dragged me into the kitchen for that? He’s just a friend David, he’s having a hard time at the moment, so I’m letting him stay with us until he finds his feet.”

The cobalt drake was furiously shaking his head long before Tyler had finished. “Don’t give me that shit” he spat in a quiet, unbridled rage. “I’m not a fucking idiot, don’t treat me like one! I can fucking well see what he’s dressed in! And your fucking leering couldn’t have been any more obvious if you were commentating on what you were looking at! So for fucks sake, come clean with me now!”

“What?! Oh, David…” Tyler said contemptuously, shaking his head in disbelief. “It’s not like that AT ALL.” He stared at his brother, holding his breath to continue, but the concept was so ridiculous that words failed him.

David balled his claws into a fist. “That’s BULLSHIT lie! You aren’t even attempting to explain the anything here!” David leant in further, his low voice thick with savage disgust. “What is he Tyler? Is he your little rent boy? Your little poke Master?” He wasn’t teasing. There was not the slightest bit of humour in his accusation. This was real.

“NO!” Tyler roared in his brothers face, before quickly checking his voice. This wasn’t a conversation he wanted Rob overhearing. “No, as a matter of fact he’s not David. But so what if he was? Would you have a problem with that?” Tyler countered indignantly.

“fucking yes!” David exclaimed exaggeratedly, making it look painful to have express the obvious. “I’m not having you go all bent on me Tyler! Not my fucking brother!”

Tyler sighed. “Well David, that would be your problem if that was the case. But lucky for you, it’s not. I told you. He’s just a friend who has nowhere else to go.”

David held up three fingers. “Alright then Tyler, I’ll buy your story if you can answer me these questions. One!” The blue drake peeled one of his finders down. “How come I’ve never seen you bring a chick home to fuck? You’re always here every fucking night, so don’t give me any bullshit that you go around making booty calls.”

David’s face must have flushed red. Partly from embarrassment, and partly from anger at David bringing up such a sensitive topic so aggressively. “David, why do you fucking think? Look at me, do you seriously think I get a tenth of the opportunities you do? It’s a different world for me. What’s wrong with you? Me not getting much action doesn’t mean that I’m gay!”

“TWO!” David pointedly moved on. “Why the fuck did you just eyeball him for half an hour if there’s nothing going on?”
“Because he fucking grew David!” Tyler spat. David cocked his head dangerously. Tyler needed to expand on that one. “Look, you saw him last night didn’t you? He came up to here on me!” Tyler gestured to the top of his shoulder. “You saw him last night! He’s grown like 6 fucking inches in a day! How can you not notice that?”

“Bullshit!’ David angrily dismissed. Tyler angrily clasped at the side of his own head.

“What do you mean bullshit? Try to fucking remember! You must have noticed how small he was, it kind of stood out as a feature! He doesn’t look anything like he did now! Are you blind?!

“Three.” David ploughing through his brother’s protests, pulling his last remaining finger down, leaving his hand in a fist. “You tell me Tyler, what kind of person dresses like… like that?!” he sat, pointing in the general direction of Rob.

“David, your worldliness continues to amaze me” Tyler said sarcastically. “He’s dressed up like that because of the same fucking reason. He was far too small to fit into any of my clothes this morning, so I gave him some of my teenage rags. You must recognise them, I wore them for fucking years!”

David shook his head in resigned irritation. “So basically Tyler, I’m given a choice between believing that your friend grew 6 inches in one day, or the whole situation being exactly what it looks like. Tell me, which one do you think I’m gonna go with? Which one would you if the situation was reversed?”

“I wouldn’t give a fuck if you were gay!” Tyler said without hesitation. It was true, but entirely the wrong answer in the situation.

David grimaced as he shook his head angrily. “Well I do, Tyler.” He picked his enormous bulk up violently as he turned to leave the kitchen. “I guess…” he said almost remorsefully. “I guess we’ve both learnt something about each other tonight then.” He held a hated gaze before turning and stomping out of the kitchen.

Tyler almost thought that David was going to punch the rabbit as he passed him on the way to the stairwell, but the cobalt drake simply snarled his teeth, avoiding eye contact.

There was a long awkward pause as they waited for David to finish stoping up the stairs, down the hallway and eventually slam his door shut. “I’m sorry Tyler, I shouldn’t have come here…” Rob started, but the purple drake waved him dismissively.

“No man, I’m fucking embarrassed about that. Look, I’m really sorry, Ok? I don’t know what’s gotten into him. It’s cool for you to stay here as long as you like, do you understand?” he asked the rabbit sincerely.

He nodded. “Yeah, thanks for that. Hopefully I don’t stay in your way for too much longer, I think things will sort themselves out quickly now.”

Tyler nodded, but his attention soon trailed to the whole rabbit spilling out of his clothes issue. “Look, Rob, can I just be blunt and come out with it? You’ve grown, like, a lot. Suddenly. Today.”

The rabbit nodded. “Yeah, I’ve noticed that too…” he said with an embarrassed smile. “It’s been happening all day, at first I thought the clothes were shrinking, or something. But then the world sort of changed around me, and I felt different. I didn’t realise how much taller I was until I saw you just before though. It’s kind of crazy.”

“yeah, it is.” Tyler agreed. “So how is this happening?”

The rabbit shrugged, the movement sliding his tight shirt further up his torso, but the tension kept it up as his elbows returned downwards. “Honestly man, I don’t know. It seems to have been happening gradually through the day, for the most part.”

“For the most part?” Tyler pressed the qualifier.

The rabbit nodded. “yeah, but you know how I was shorting out your toaster and stuff this morning?” he asked sheepishly. No, Tyler thought. The television was much more expensive. You should have listed that as your example, not the toaster.

The rabbit continued. “Well, that kind of kept happening throughout the day. I manage to electrocute myself on the security door, a computer and just a few moments ago on a parked car as I walked past it crossing the road. That was a big one.”

“Does it hurt?” Tyler asked. The rabbit shook his head.

“no, not at all. In fact, it feels kind of… really good. But that’s when I seem to have a bit of a growth spurt, when I get electrocuted. It’s like… it’s like a surge of energy that makes me bigger, I guess.“

“Are you still cold?” Tyler asked sceptically. The rabbit was making extraordinary claims, but he was certainly backing it up with extraordinary evidence. Rob shrugged. “You tell me…” he asked, offering his hand. Tyler gasped as he touched it.

Rob didn’t take offense. “To be honest, I’ll feel a lot better once I’m giving SOMETHING back in this little setup here.”

“Ha, cool then.” Tyler smiled. Well, I’ll walk you to the shop tomorrow morning, and you can stick around while I show you how things are done, and then leave you to it in the afternoon. Sound like a plan?”

.

The movement brought him to within several inches of the hallway lamp, which was apparently enough to make it short through the rabbit. The globe loudly burst as a think white bolt of electricity struck the rabbit mid stride. “ungh!” Rob groaned in pleasant surprise after the jolt.

Tyler didn’t actually see the rabbit grow, but his shorts told the story. The overstretched fabric finally burst long the seam of the outside of the right leg. Tyler was left shaking his head in disbelief. That was the image he spent most of the night worrying about as he lay in bed.What happened if things started to get out of control there? There seemed to be ample opportunities for that to happen. It was all frivolous to worry over, but Tyler wouldn’t be himself if he didn’t care.

Tyler woke up the next morning with a knock on the door. Well, that immediately ruled out David. He quickly dressed in some underwear before he opened the door. “What do you need Rob?”

The rabbit was leaning in from the side of the doorway so that only his head, a shoulder and a stabilising hand were visible. Judging by the steam emanating off his body and water on his fur, he was fresh out of a shower. Wait. On second glance, that was ice, not water. And frost, not steam. “Hey Tyler, sorry to wake you. But…”

“What. The. Fuck.” Tyler interrupted as he stayed fixated on the rabbit’s frozen fur.

Rob looked at the gaping dragon patiently. “I know, it’s a bit odd isn’t it… but you were right, water can freeze on me now I guess.”

Tyler looked into the rabbit’s brown eyes. It was an upwards angle. The rabbit was leaning into the doorway, but he was still looking up at eyes. “You’ve grown again, haven’t you?” Tyler asked cautiously.

“Well, that too, I guess.” Rob said as if an aside. “I’ve been feeling taller, and now you look smaller, so I guess I did. You’re like a barometer for this. I don’t realise to what degree until I see you.” He said, smiling.

“So um, anyway…” the rabbit continued. “ I’m sorry, but would I be able to borrow some of your clothes? I just have this towel and the stuff you gave me yesterday, but I don’t think they’d fit on my anymore.”

The drake was speechless.
“Plus ah, they’re all dirty and… ripped now, so I don’t really have anything at all to wear….” The rabbit trailed off.

“Yeah,” Tyler said nodding. “Sure, I’ll… what did you want to wear?” he asked distractedly.

“Whatever you have to spare, I’ll be happy with anything. Don’t waste your good stuff on me, I’ll be happy with anything that keeps me decent.

Tyler wandered over to his closet and fumbled through his collection, gathering a reasonably nice shirt, some shorts, and… was he meant to give him his underwear? Would that be weird? Would it be rude not to? In the end he buried a pair into the pile and handed them off to the rabbit.

‘Thanks man, that’s greatly appreciated, I’ll leave you alone now.” He said, closing the door. Tyler shrugged. Nothing about that exchange was normal.

He started making his own preparations for the day when the rabbit knocked on the door again. “l’m super sorry about this…’Rob began as Tyler opened the door. The rabbit was wearing nothing but the shorts, holding the shirt folded in his hands. Now he was standing properly in full view, Tyler could see that he must have been a good four inches taller than him. His eyes widened.

“…you wouldn’t happen to have anything a little… bigger would you?” the rabbit asked handing the shirt back to him.
Tyler looked at the shirt in his hands. “Bigger?” he inquired dumbly.

“Well, it fits all right, but it’s a bit tight. I hate to be fussy, but I’m just thinking back to yesterday when I ripped your clothes because they were a bit small. I figure I’d be less of an ass being a bit fussy now, than later handing you a busted shirt. At the end of the day.”

Tyler took the shirt from the rabbit, before looking up at him again. “Well, how much bigger are you planning on getting today?” He asked.

Tyler looked back at his eyes in confusion. “You’re not what?” he asked.

“I’m not planning on getting bigger today.” He replied. His voice was deeper, Tyler realised. He thought back to the little rabbit he had rescued two days earlier. Rob looked and sounded nothing like him.

“But you’re going to grow anyway, aren’t you.” Tyler pointed out, rather than ask.

The rabbit gave a sheepish grin. “I suppose so. I’m just… I guess I’m building a contingency.”

Tyler nodded. “Yes, they are.”

“So…’ Rob started awkwardly. “When did you plan on leaving this morning?”

“Maybe.” The rabbit shrugged, averting his gaze to his fidgeting hands resting on tabletop. “I don’t know. This is kind of new for me, I don’t really know what to expect. But there’s no point in worrying about it until it gets to that point, is there? I mean, that’s not going to change anything is it? The whole thing might sort of just go away, like it just sort of came. Things tend to sort themselves out.”

“But what if it doesn’t go away?” Tyler insisted. “What if it just keeps getting worse?”

The rabbit smiled, rolling his eyes playfully. “Four days ago I wasn’t in this country. I could have worried about not passing thought customs, about losing my luggage, or missing my flight. But then three days ago I didn’t have to worry about any of that anymore. But I could have worried about not being able to find accommodation. Then two days ago I didn’t have to worry about that at all. But I could have worried about my first day of College, about whether or not I’d fit in well with anyone, and then later about whether I'd be thrown in jail for being a terrorist... that was a bit one. But yesterday things went well, and I don’t have to worry about that now either. I could worry about… this” the rabbit gestured to himself “…today if I wanted to, but why bother when tomorrow this could all be over, and I’ll just have a fresh bunch of other stuff to worry about. Does that make sense?”

Tyler nodded as he considered this perspective. “Yes, it makes a lot of sense, actually.” Tyler admitted. “But surely, if you looked at life like that, then nothing matters. I mean, this would have to be considered a health issue wouldn’t it? Not being able to make friends, or getting turned around at customs… they would all suck, but they’re really just setbacks. This… well, who knows, you could die.” Tyler finished dramatically.

The rabbit shrugged again. “I could die from a falling piano today walking down a street. But I’m not going to worry about it. I suppose the only thing I really worry about… is not finding the time to just enjoy life.”

Tyler sighed. “I guess I wish I could be more like you then, in a way.”

“Why?” Rob asked. “What’s wrong with you? If you were more like me, you wouldn’t have a cool store. You’d be a completely different person. There’s nothing wrong with what you are. It’s kind of nice to have you worry enough for the both of us.”

“Well then…” Tyler seized the moment. “Will you indulge me this morning, instead of manning the store tonight?”

“Sure.” The rabbit said.

“I want introduce you to a professor I know at college… let him have a look over you and just see what he thinks.”
Rob’s face and ears dropped. “What, like have him study me?” He asked timidly.

“Maybe, if he’s interested. But that would be completely up to you man, if you aren’t comfortable with that then you don’t have to go along with it. But I would be interested in finding out what he has to say about all of this.”

The rabbit looked away. “Would that make you feel more at ease with me?” The rabbit asked. Tyler didn’t have to be a body language expert to realise that the rabbit was incredibly uncomfortable with the prospect.

“It would make me feel better to have another thought on this, yes.” He said.

The rabbit turned back to Tyler. “But don’t you have to go and work in your store this morning?” the rabbit asked.

“Well that was the plan, but to be honest…” Tyler put on a cheesy smile. “Something bigger has come up.”
1152111211111.title: Tyler has second thoughts about this plan…...

11521112111111.content:
Dr. Peter Dell was a somewhat tall for a skink, standing just shy of eye level to Tyler. How was also quite young for a professor, spending his life to date in the academic system gradually progressing through the ranks. His field was biology, a minor of Tyler’s, and the purple drake enjoyed a reasonably comfortable relationship with him.

It came as a relief to Tyler when he found the professor shuffling some papers in his office that morning. Leaving Rob in the hallway, the drake knocked softly on his door.

“Oh, Tyler.” The professor said as he recognised one of his former students. “What’s brought you back here?”
“Well…” the drake started awkwardly, “it’s somewhat extracurricular, but I was hoping I could get your guidance on something that has come up, if you aren’t too busy?” Tyler asked.

“Actually, my day is pretty full starting in about half an hour. I’ve got some preparations to do, so unless it’s a quick one, would you mind coming back Thursday afternoon? I can put some consultation time aside if you’d like?”

Tyler shook his head. There was no way he was waiting until Thursday. “No, it should only take a second, if that’s alright”. Tyler lied.

“Well then, fire away!” the skink said, gesturing him in as he placed his hands down on his paperwork, affording the purple drake his full attention.

Tyler approached his desk. “I have this rabbit friend who’s recently had this odd medical condition, as I was just wondering if you had any ideas about what it could be?”

The skink furrowed his brows. “Tyler, I’m not a medical practitioner, I’m not in the business of diagnosis…”

“I know, Peter.” Tyler interrupted carefully. “I’m not after a diagnosis, I was just wondering if you knew of the term for his phenomena.”

“Phenomina?!” the skink said in mock impression. “Well, that’s much more appropriate than ‘medical condition’. Go ahead.”

“Well, yesterday I noticed his body temperature had dropped dramatically…”

“Take him to the hospital.” The skink said suddenly alarmed.

Tyler gave an uneasy smile. “No, it gets worse than that. Later last night, his temperature was clearly below room temperature. And this morning when he was showering, the water froze into ice in his fur. It’s like his body is generating cold.”

The skink cocked his head as he tried to read the Drake.

“Look, I know it sounds unusual, but I brought him in today to show you… if you wouldn’t mind taking a look for yourself?”

The skink sat a moment puzzled. “Tyler, I just told you I’m full on today, why do you think I’d be up for… whatever this is?” he asked.

“Its not a trick, or a joke, or a scam.” Tryler reassured him. “Rob!” he called out of the office. Instantly, the white rabbit poked his head through the doorway, his long ears facing to attention. “Peter, this is my friend Rob…” Tyler said as the rabbit walked into the room. Rob fidgeted nervously before offering his hand to the skink.

Peter looked carefully between the rabbit and the drake before accepting the offer.

“Ah!” he recoiled in shock from the rabbit’s brief grip. He stared in disbelief a moment longer before finally laughing.

“Ok, that was clever. How did you do that?” he asked the rabbit.

Rob shrugged. “I’m not really doing anything, sir.”

“Peter, this is real.” Tyler said seriously. “Touch him anywhere on his body, you’ll see it’s just as cold.”

Peter shook his head in disgust. “Tyler, I’m not about to start touching students. Fun is fun, but that’s clearly crossing a big line.”

“Well can you at least touch his forehead?” Tyler asked. “Or take his temperature? You know me Peter, when have I ever tried to pull a prank on you?”

The skink shifted his attention between the drake and the rabbit. “You’re…” he trailed off before scoffing. “I can’t believe I’m about to fall for this, but you’re being serious aren’t you?”

“Yes.” Tyler said absolutely. “Just feel his forehead.” Tyler insisted.

Rob bent down and leant towards the skink, offering his forehead. His brow was furrowed and his nose twitched nervously.

Carefully, Peter leant forwards and placed the back of his hand on the rabbit’s forehead.

“Ugh!” he cried out in surprise and disgust as his hand pulled away. Then as if to confirm, he touched it again.

“I can’t even hold my hand on it, it’s so cold!” he said to himself in amazement. Suddenly he grabbed the rabbit’s shoulder, and then his hand.

“He’s cold all over.” Tyler said, as if answering the thought.

“This is… amazing!” the skink said numbly. “I’ve never felt anything so cold in my life, how are you not frozen solid?” The skink asked the rabbit.

Rob shrugged nervously.

“Ok so that’s one of the odd things…” Tyler began.

The skink raised his eyebrows “There’s more!?”

“well…” Tyler paused to articulate. Electricity wasn’t really his field. “If Rob makes contact with an active electrical device, he seems to short them out, and he attracts the electric current, so he gets electrocuted.”

“Well…” Rob began quietly. “I don’t have to actually touch it anymore; it’s just if I get close to it…” he corrected.

The skink eyed the pair. “I think I understand you. But people get electrocuted on everyday appliances all the time, so how can you discern that he isn’t just unlucky or reckless?”

Rob gave Tyler a nervous look before slowly moving his hand towards a small desk lamp that sat on the professor’s desk. The three followed his hand in silence as it inched towards the bulb.

BANG! The light flashed out when the rabbit’s hand was about six inches away from it, sending a short bolt of white electricity up the rabbit’s arm. Tyler was expecting it, but the explosion still caused him to jump. The skink was outright startled, flinching quite comically. The rabbit didn’t move at all, save for a dopey little grin forming on his face.

“It’s repeatable, Peter.” Tyler said. “He’s broken a fair few appliances at home now, and some on campus. All within a day.”

“Didn’t that hurt?” The skink asked Rob in dismay.

“No, sir.”

“Well then…” the professor said raising his eyebrows. “That’s two things I’m at a loss to explain.”

“The third is a big one…” Tyler began, enjoying the look of expectation he managed to provoke from the professor.
“Less than two days ago, he was this tall.” Tyler said, placing a flat hand against his shoulder.

The professor looked between the drake’s hand and the top of the rabbit’s head. “That would be about a foot the difference.” He estimated.

“yeah, probably about that.” Tyler agreed, looking up at the rabbit, which blushed a bit in embarrassment.

The professor was shaking his head. “Well, I suppose growth would be considered a normal biological phenomena. And it’s not unusual for an individual to have a spurt in their late teens or even early twenties, so this one does have a rational explanation based on current understandings.”

“No, he grew a foot in less than two days.” Tyler insisted.

“It’s true, sir." Rob added. "I've been growing for over a day now. It was about this time yesterday that I started noticing it.”

The professor studied the rabbit for a moment. “I’m still not really convinced; you haven’t presented me with anything other than testimony backed up on speculation. It’s far more likely that you are both mistaken.”

“Come on Peter.” Tyler tried to reason. “You’ve felt how cold he is, and seen how he… shorts out things and gets electrocuted. Why is this so hard to accept?”

“Because that’s not how it works, Tyler. I have seen two phenomena I can’t readily explain. And you have presented a third one to me which I can. While your claim is certainly extraordinary, I see nothing to back it up. Rob is unquestioningly a very tall rabbit. If I recall correctly, the mean lapin height is four and a half feet, and anything up to four foot eleven is considered average. Your friend here looks about five foot five, maybe six. That’s easily within two standard deviations. That puts him somewhere in the high single digit percentile, exceptional but not extraordinary.”

Tyler was getting frustrated. “It’s not his size that's unusual, it’s how he’s suddenly got there.”

The skink was shaking his head. “For your accounts to be accurate, Rob would have needed to almost double his bodyweight in a twenty four hour period. Where did all that mass come from? Clearly, it’s impossible on many levels though many fields. It would fundamentally alter our understanding of the universe. If you think your friend is still growing at that pace, well then that suddenly becomes a hypothesis with predictive properties. It’s a claim we can test. But I would be remiss to simply accept it and offer any insight based on your claims.”

“I am still growing, sir.” The rabbit mumbled.

“Well then…” The skink rested a hand on his jaw as he considered the rabbit.

“Would you be willing to participate in some informal experiments? Nothing too invasive, just some tests to try and measure some of these phenomena which have been demonstrated and discussed. We can get a better understanding on what is exactly happening here.”

The rabbit shuffled nervously as he eyed Tyler uneasily. The purple drake nodded his head in encouragement.
11521112111111.title: The rabbit shrugged. "Ok, I guess..."

115211121111111.content:
“Why do you always address some people as ‘sir’ every time you talk to them?” Tyler asked Rob as they sat in the hallway. Peter had cancelled his classes for the morning in order to prepare and conduct the voluntary experiments, leaving the students to wait until he was ready.

The rabbit was clearly out of his element. His elongated incisors softly chewed his bottom lip as his ears lay back and sharply flat. His brown eyes were wide and restless, looking everywhere but at Tyler. “I don’t know.” The rabbit finally answered. “Isn't it respectful?”

“Not really...” Tyler replied cautiously. “It sounds a bit… weird, to be honest. It's fine, I guess, but over here, you’d usually refer to their position and their last name if you wanted to be respectful. Like ‘Doctor Del’. And you wouldn’t say it every sentence.”

“Sorry…” the rabbit murmured.

“Don’t apologise." Tyler insisted. "I just thought you might want some advice, I guess.”

The rabbit fidgeted on his seat.

“You’re nervous aren’t you?” Tyler broke the silence. “What happened with not worrying too much?”

The rabbit shrugged, looking at the floor. “I don’t like being the centre of attention. Or being inspected, or studied or judged. I’ll be fine, It’s just… I’m not used to it, and I don’t enjoy it.”

Tyler felt slightly guilty. He knew the rabbit was only here because he wanted him to be. Was he taking advantage of the situation? The rabbit probably felt pressured to go along with Tyler. Was he really in a position to refuse?

“You don’t have to do this.” Tyler offered.

“I know.” The rabbit said bluntly.

There was another long, awkward pause before the rabbit loudly exhaled. “But I guess it won’t hurt to know more about it."

The door across the hall opened. “Ok guys.” the professor gestured them into the lab.

The lab was small, and mostly filled by various apparatus, some less readily identifiable than the others. It would have looked intimidating enough without the three cameras positioned to view the centre of the room from different angles, all sporting active red LED’s.

The rabbit looked outright panicked. “Are you going to write an article about me and publish this publically?!”

The skink shook his head emphatically. “Oh, hell no! Do you know what it would take for me to get approval for a study like that? It would take weeks of formal planning and paperwork to get ethics approval for a start, and then there's funding and resources... those articles you read in journals take years to go from planning to published. This is purely informal, for the three of us better understand you. It would cost me my career if I passed any of this on.”

“Then what’s with all the cameras?” Tyler asked.

The skink stared at him a moment, puzzled. “Because we’re conducting experiments... this is how you do them properly. Informal doesn’t mean sloppy.”

The rabbit steeled himself. “What do you want me to do to start with?” he asked, clearly wanting to get things over with.

“Please take a step on the scales over here and we will get a starting measurement, if you wouldn't mind.” the skink gestured towards what looked to be a simple bathroom scale.

The rabbit obliged. The scale shorted out as his first foot landed on it. Rob grunted in surprise.

The skink drew a line through something on his clipboard. “Ok, are you still alright Rob?” he asked. The rabbit nodded.

“Step back please” he said to the rabbit as he collected the dead scale, replacing it with one that looked far more expensive. He crudely placed an upturned white plastic bucket on top of it.

“Now, I would like to get digital measurements as a preference. This bucket should offer enough electrical resistance to keep you from shorting it out.Would you mind stepping up on the bucket please Rob?” The skink asked, offering his hand.

The rabbit didn’t take it, easily managing the step up on his own.

“Very good, stand still please.” The professor instructed as he read the scales. “Fifty eight kilograms, four hundred and tirty-sev… eight grams.” He said into a recording device before taking more notes.

The rabbit raised his eyebrows in surprise, his ears shooting up and forwards. “I was thirty one kilograms last time I weighed myself.”

“We won't record that measurement.” The skink replied. “Or even this one, until it settles. Are you standing still?” he asked the rabbit without looking up.

“Yes.” The rabbit mumbled.

The skink stared at the scales patiently. “Tyler, would you mind switching with Rob?” he asked after a moment.

“Me? Why?" the drake asked. Rob stepped down as Tyler approached.

“Just for a point of comparison.” The skink said as he helped the purple drake up onto the bucket. “Stand as still as you can.” He instructed as he patiently studied the scale.

“Ok, now could Rob please get back on?” he asked after about thirty seconds. The two swapped positions again as the skink studied the scales for another good minute.

“Ok, you can get off now, thank you”. The professor instructed as he started writing down notes. “Well, that didn’t go as expected at all.” He said to himself. The students waited for an elaboration.

“That is a very accurate set of scales.” The skink began as he wrote. “There was a bit of noise… in the measurements. You expect that because no one can stand perfectly still. But I did notice an increasing pattern with Rob which wasn’t present for Tyler. I recorded his weight increasing by a gram roughly every five seconds. Which is consistent with your growth hypothesis.” He said, finally looking up from his notes. “A gram every five seconds is significant; that would work out to about seventeen kilograms a day.”

Tyler converted that in his mind. “that would be… what, about forty ponds?”

The skink nodded. “Which would actually be somewhat consistent with your original ‘slightly less than two days’ estimate..." he said, pointing at Tyler. "..if we WERE to record Rob’s original thirty one kilogram starting value. But it's far too slow for your twenty four hour timeframe.” He said, pointing at Rob.

The rabbit scowled slightly as he looked away. “That’s because I also get bigger when I’m electrocuted. It’s not always gradual.” He mumbled.

The skink raised his eyebrows. “You never mentioned that before.”

Tyler was surprised, thinking back on the original conversation. “Sorry, I thought we did.” Tyler apologised. “He claims his growth is spurred by electricity.”

“Well, that’s also something we can test for then.” The professor said as he wrote down more notes. “But right now, let’s finish out initial measurements. Would you mind standing up against the chart on that wall?

The skink measured the rabbit’s height – five foot six and a half, and using a rather large thermometer, estimated his body temperature to be at approximately minus fifty three degrees Celsius.

“Blood pressure and heart rate otherwise normal” the skink checked off his list. “Right then, there are two additional tests I would like to perform, so long as you are willing, Rob.” The skink said as he went to wheel a large heavy rectangular device to the centre of the room.

Rob looked at it with concern.

“It’s just an industrial heater.” The skink reassured him. “I would like to test if your body temperature in different environments. And now that we have established a potential pattern of increasing weight, I would like to do it with you standing on scales.”

The rabbit reluctantly stood back up onto the bucket.

“Fifty eight kilograms, eight hundred and fifty one grams That appears to be an expected extrapolation.” the professor said formally.

“Please stay still.” He instructed the rabbit as he switched the heater on, quickly heating the small room. “If either of you feel faint or otherwise queer due to the room temperature, then speak out. I want to raise it significantly for a short period of time, but I don’t want you guys having any health issues.” He said.

“I don’t feel temperature.” The rabbit stated flatly.

The professor turned the switch off a few minutes later. Tyler was beginning to find the heat unbearable. “Fifty degrees Celsius. The skink noted. “How are you coping with this, Rob?”

“I don’t feel temperature.” the rabbit repeated impatiently.

The skink quickly took down some more notes. “Ok then, the starting weight at this temperature is fifty eight kilograms, nine hundred and eleven grams.”

Tyler was sweating profusely. The professor timed out ten minutes before he took the rabbit’s temperature again. “Still minus fifty three degrees. He said. He then looked at the scale again. “fifty nine kilograms, eighty three grams.” He noted, before activating the lab’s ventilation system.

The room erupted as unseen but clearly sizeable large fans suddenly sucked the hot, stale air up and out of the room. “Oh, thank god.” Tyler said with relief as he felt cooler air flow against his sweaty skin and clothes.

“We're almost done, just one more test to go.” The skink said as he wandered out back. “I may be a few minutes, I didn’t prepare this one.” He left the two students alone.

Tyler wandered up to the Rob nervously, the rabbit still poised on the white bucket. “Um, wow. Forty pounds a day? That’s really… that’s fucking fast man, isn’t it?”

1152111211111111.content:
anger flashed across the rabbit’s face, his ears facing back and sharply down. “We already knew that!” he snapped. “All this has fucking around has done is put a number on it.”

Tyler was taken aback; he hadn’t seen Rob like this before.

“Hey, calm down man.” Tyler said defensively. “There’s no need to get worked up, we can go right now if you’re not up for it anymore.”

“I was never up for it!” The rabbit spat, his eyes pointed furiously at the floor. “And I’m not staying up here while I wait for him to come back.” Rob got off the bucket, his thick paw hitting the ground with a soft thud.

“Well then, we’ll say that we’ve had enough, and he’ll…”

“I’ve come this far, I’ll fucking finish it!” The rabbit interrupted.

“Hey, why are you so angry?” Tyler asked, much to his immediate regret as Rob’s angry brown eyes finally locked onto his.

“Because I don’t want to be here!” the rabbit snapped, taking an angry step forward. “Because you KNOW I don’t want to be here! This whole setup… I was happy to just let it ride, But you caught me up in all this bullshit!”

Tyler was intimidated by the rabbit. His voice was suprisingly loud and deep, and he was frame was comparatively imposing. “Rob, come on!” Tyler protested as he took half a step backwards. “I never made you do anything, I’ve just asked and you’ve agreed! I’ve said all along we can eave when you want to!”

The rabbit gave a sharp laugh. “Yeah, that’s all been through passive aggressive bullshit and you know it.”

Rob held his gaze for a tense moment, before he finally shifted it back to the floor. A very silent pause followed, before the rabbit sighed. “Look, I’m sorry. I don’t know why I’m so angry. I don’t usually get angry… so I don’t know how to handle it well, ok? I'm just stressed. I'm not used to that either.” His eyes were everywhere but Tyler.

Tyler was relieved that Rob had called down, but he wasn’t willing to let it slide. “I haven’t been passive aggressive.” Tyler calmly asserted.

The rabbit paused for thought. “That’s not the word for it. I’m sorry. But I have been compelled.”

“What, were you afraid I’m going to kick you out of the house if you didn’t come along?”

The rabbit shook his head slowly. “No, I wasn’t compelled through fear; I was compelled through my own feeling of obligation. I’d happily help out in your store Tyler, or do any other menial task or favour. But I didn’t want to do this. I didn’t realise how much until I was in here though, so it’s my fault for not just saying no.”

“So why don’t we just go now?” Tyler asked again.

“Because then it’s all for nothing isn’t it? One last thing, and you can get what you wanted. If we leave now then I’ve still gone through this and neither of us are happy.”

“Ok then…” Peter abruptly ended the confrontation as entered the room, completely oblivious to the tension in the atmosphere. Rob raised an eyebrow as he noticed he held what looked to be some kind of cattle prod.

“Rob, I would like to end this session by testing your claim that electrical shocks cause growth. I have a device that will allow me to safely give you a high voltage, low current electrical shock. Would you mind standing back on the bucket?” He asked.

“Whatever.” The rabbit signed in resignation as he made his way back onto the scales.

“fifty nine kilograms, one hundred and sixty seven grams.” The professor noted. “Alright,” the skink fiddled with the prod. “I’m going to start this on a relatively low voltage, about two thousand. As a quick point of comparison, an everyday static electric charge can be hundreds of thousands of volts. At low amperage, this will be completely safe. Are you ready?”

The rabbit nodded. The professor gently placed the end of the prod onto his thigh. Rob’s eyes closed in anticipation, his ears pointing down and slightly to the side as he bit his bottom lip. And then gave a weak grunt before the professor removed the prod to study the scale and quietly started to take notes.

“Was that it?” the rabbit asked slightly confused.

“That was the first one. I’d like to try several such shocks in increasing voltages. So long as you are willing and don’t feel an unreasonable level of pain.

“That didn’t hurt at all. I’ve told you, getting shocked doesn’t hurt me.” The rabbit said irritably.

“I’d still rather approach this cautiously…” the skink said as he fiddled with the prod. He held it against the rabbits thigh a second time. “Ten thousand volts. are you ready?” he asked the rabbit, who tensed up and nodded in response.

It lead to the same result, the rabbit barely acknowledging the shock while the professor recorded the results.

The professor looked up at Tyler once he had finished writing. “This is kind of awkward for one person to execute, would you mind administering the shocks while I study the measurements and take notes?”

Tyler was taken aback. “I don’t want to shock him!” he said.

“Oh, just do it so we can get this over with!” Rob snapped at the purple drake. His sudden outburst was enough to jolt Tyler into compliance.

Tyler placed the prod on the rabbit somewhat reluctantly after the professor gave him a brief crash course. The skink aquatted in front of the scales, resting his clipboard on his knees ready to take notes as nessesary. “Ok, when you’re ready.”

Tyler flicked the switch. The next moment was chaos. The prod made a lout popping sound, before emitting a bright white, continuous bolt of energy directly into the rabbit. Tyler instantly panicked as he fumbled uselessly at the switch. It wasn’t turning off. The electricity was flowing freely into the Rob’s body for a good few seconds before the purple Drake gathered the sense to throw it away across the room.

For the first time, Tyler saw the rabbit grow. His eyes were immediately drawn to the halo of white fur that abruptly spilled out between the rabbit’s parting shirt and shorts. The shirt slid a good three quarters of an inch up his elongating torso, exposing the rabbit’s navel to the daylight.

There were other elements to the spurt which he witnessed through his periphery. The rabbit’s tail rose a good inch higher as his lengthening feet spurred his torso further up into the air. His fur expanded from nothing as it slid over new muscles. He saw the slack in the rabbit’s pants dissipate as his hips and thighs widened, affording his growing package more definition as the elastic audibly withdrew slightly down the rabbit’s pelvis.

The growth lasted only as long as the shock, but it was a powerful set of movement. Tyler stepped back out of reflex, staring up at the rabbit in shock.

Rob smiled nervously as he stretched his enlarged body, his spine and shoulders loudly popping as he did so. “Hey, can we take that thing home?” he nervously joke. It fell flat on the two speechless withesses.

“..ok, that’s enough.” the skink said, before checking the scales one last time. “Sixty four kilograms, two hundred and twenty grams.” He said without emotion. “twenty one grams.” He distantly corrected himself a moment later.

The rabbit got down off the scales with a slightly louder thud than before. Tyler stared at the rabbit with wide eyes. He was obviously taller. Five foot nine? It would have to be about that. And while the rabbit was still reasonably lean, there were more contours visible through his stretching shirt. Tyler's eyes opened in surprise when he saw that the rabbit was sporting the beginning of an erection through his tight shorts.

The rabbit noticed Tyler examining him, and turned away. “It’s the electric shock… “ he mumbled meekly.

Tyler was immediately embarrassed himself, and the two spent a good moment poiniantly not noticing each other.

The skink was looking at his clip board, but he was no longer writing.

“Ok, so here is my initial hypothesis. The subject’s body is absorbing energy from the environment, and converting that energy into mass. The subject appears to take in heat energy from his environment, which is why he appears cold to touch. Using the measured temperature of minus fifty three degrees as a base, I increased the temperature difference between subject and environment by roughly forty seven percent. Growth accelerated by the same percentage, increasing from one gram every five seconds, to one gram every three point five seconds. This showed a strong correlation between growth and room temperature.”

The skink turned the page on his clipboard. “It also appears that his body is also converting electricity into mass. A significant increase was recorded when an unrecorded amount entered the subject’s body. Normally, electricity would flow through an earthed object into the ground. However, it would appear that the subject is his own grounding force, which would explain how he is shorting out electric equipment, and report no pain from shocks.”

The skink looked up form his notes. “Further research is necessary. I would like to study samples such as blood, fur and saliva, as well as test how the subject responds to other forms of energy, such as kinetic and noise.”

The professor looked up at Rob. “Would I be able to book you in for some additional tests tomorrow after I have analysed the data here, and given the results more thought?”

Rob looked to Tyler, his brown eyes stoic but his ears still suggested that he was tense and irritable.

11521112111111112.content:
“So, was that valuable to you?” Rob asked as they left the lab.

Tyler thought a moment. “Yeah, in a way, I always prefer any knowledge to ignorance, I suppose. Why, what do you think?”

The rabbit shook his head. “It doesn’t change anything, does it? I mean, I’m glad you’re happy, hopefully it satisfies you. But unless it’s knowledge that I can put to use, ignorance is bliss. I mean, why worry about something you can’t change?”

“Did any of that worry you?”

Rob didn’t appear to acknowledge the question straight away. The two made their way outside into the mid-afternoon sun. “I didn’t realise it was so fast.” The rabbit replied so long after the original question it was almost without context. “And I didn’t realise I was that cold. My weight just kept creeping up... I guess it’s brought it to the front of my mind. It’s going to take some effort to push it all back.”

After what seems like an eternity of ringing, the phone finally clicks, her voice flutters on the other end, "Afternoon, how's my favorite shop doing."

"O good, good," saying though unable to hide hiss giddiness nor his tantalizing Baritone voice over the phone. "Hey your supernaturals comics came in today." Tyler's large dragon tail wagging back and forth feverishly.

"O that's good. Hey you wouldn't mind waiting a little after five today. Had to cover my friend's shift."

"Anything for one of our favorites," stupidly winking over the phone like she could see it.

"Okay, see you after five. Tell Tyler I said hi David..." It clicks and she hangs up...

She thought I was David, dropping the phone from the side of his face and to the floor...

Tyler punched the door frame with the curtain. The building shook again, the lights flickering a little this time. This wasn't right, this was wrong, all wrong. He began to slide down the door frame to the ground as best as his bulk would allow. Trying to make sure he was still himself, but he wasn't. If he still wanted to be himself he would be the dwarf that everyone ignores and looks past. Just because a dragon is five foot tall doesn't mean he doesn't feel things...

At this time when Tyler felt at his lowest he would probably cry to himself to help ease the pain, hoping it would go away. His brother never knew anything outside of what he saw in his own reflection!

All the years of neglect... All those moments of being in his brother's shadow... Sometimes not even good enough to be related to his brother. All the knowledge he had not being worth a damn most times... His brother had everything he wanted. He knew if his parents had a favorite, it would probably be David. He had the looks that could be in magazines, the charisma to get anything he wanted and the attitude to not be a doormat for people. Did he just let people walk all over him, because he wasn't comfortable with it. Surely, other people could see that but no one ever showed...

For once in his life, he had the power to change that all, holding the amulet in his hand and looking at its heart-shaped jeweled center. Now that he had the look and the feel of his brother, was he still so unhappy? Was he to always remain unsatisfied and discontent?
